title: New generation transgenic techniques in rabbits

author: László Hiripi, National Agricultural Research and Innovation Centre (NARIC)

segmentation: Three, my great pleasure to talk about some transgenic rabbits here.
The.
First question is why to use transgenic rabbits as in the previous talk you have seen from Oscar, you can do anything in my it's way too white to use rabbit as a model.
If you want to make a model for human disease, sometimes the mouse or a rat model is not the best.
Here are some examples.
The prenatal development, early embryonic development in the rabbit is much much close to the human than the mice order at the next, which is very important.
Utter sclerosis.
You can make some nice experiments.
In in transgenic mice and rats.
But the lipid metabolism and the lipid synthesis is totally different in the mice than in the human.
So if you want to use a better model, you should go to rabbit.
There are some sponte mutants which can give some similar phenotype than humans, and if you make a transgenic rabbit model it's really a good model for the.
The author of sclerosis.
Is the same for some heart diseases.
There are some special mutations which can cause our IT Genesis in human and the.
Ion channel proteins of the of the mice and rats are again totally different from the human, so very good model can be transgenic.
Rabbits is the same for the diabetic pregnancy and you can do some nice research in rabbits in the eye because it has very big eyes comparing to mice and rats.
So a lot of retinal degeneration studies in transgenic.
Rabbit models can be done and don't forget that rabbits are very important for the antibody production and you can use transgenic techniques to boost this antibody production.
You can you can produce more antibodies in special transgenic lines, or it is possible even to use more specific antibodies.
Even humanized antibodies can be produced in.
Transgenic rabbits in Hungary.
There is a special spinoff company, or for the Institute, together with the University, which are in this business in the antibody production using a transgenic rabbit model.
So that's the models for human diseases, but.
You can even use transgenic rabbit as a buyer, a reactor you can produce medicines in the milk of transgenic rabbits.
One of the first pharmaceutical protein which was coming from a transgenic rabbit, and it's on the market was this RUCONEST.
It's a human C1 inhibitor protein, and it's for the treatment of.
Angioedema, which looks like that so it's it's really a very good model or a very good transgenic line to produce proteins.
There is another one which is not in the market, so you cannot buy it now, but hopefully soon you can buy it.
It's producing Alpha Glucosidase, which is for creating Pompe disease.
Pompe Disease is a muscle disease if you don't.
Give this medicine for the children without the Alpha, because it does, they they can die by the age of four, but you can see after the treatment.
These children are totally well and this product was produced in transgenic milk of rabbits.
So now we know.
Why are transgenic rabbit is good?
But what was the the method previously for the transgenic rabbit?
It was the old method the the conventional microinjection where using your gene video or regulatory region you microinjected into the protocols of the DNA construct and then biosurgical transfer.
You transferred it to observe the pregnant female.
To the oviduct or to the uterus?
And if you were lucky, then you got some some newborns.
But what are the problems with the transgenic rabbits for the additive transgenesis, which is the conventional method?
The problem is the efficiency.
The efficiency is just two 3% comparing to the mice where it can be 10%.
So it's really the efficiency is very low, so we need something to do.
We done it much better and targeted Transgenesis was not possible in rabbits because there was no good rabbit.
Yes says so.
That's why we need.
We needed some new technologies, new technologies and for the targeted transgenesis it was the nucleus technology.
Now you know a lot of things about the nucleus, technology from Oscar and for the additive transgenesis there is the transposon based transgenesis which was.
Down firstly, nor laboratory.
In rabbits.
What is transposon mediated transgenesis?
There are two different type of transposons but the first is the RNA transposons.
It works as a copy and paste.
It's not a very simple mechanism, so that's why they don't like it in biotechnology.
But there are DNA transposons and DNA transposons.
Work as a cut and paste, which is a very, very simple one step procedure.
And that's why it became very important in the modern biotechnology.
So we we use transposons in the biotechnology.
Not just for Transgenesis, which is the most important for me, but it's used for gene therapy and or you can use it for insertional mutagenesis.
So it's really.
It's used everywhere in the in the biotechnology.
So how this translator transposon based Transgenesis works.

It's a very simple method, you just need your gene of interest and to the five prime and to the three prime and you just have to clone repeat its sequence and this repeated sequences the recognition site for the transposase this one and if it transposes phone this recognition sites, it cuts out the sequence between these two sites.
And integrated into the genomic region, the integration is more or less.
Randomly I will.
I will talk a little.
Later.
There are different types of of transposon based methods.

We used the Sleeping Beauty system, the Sleeping Beauty system was coming from a fish from someone it fish and it was an inactive form of DNA transposon and this was reconstructed by PCR mutagenesis so then it became active.
The first version of this system was not very very effective.
So later on using.
More mutagenesis they could produce 100 times more efficient type of this system and then this system was able to produce transgenic animals.
The integration usually goes to this DNA sequence, which means that it's more or less random and it works in different species.
It works in mice.
It works in rats.
It works in fish is and that's why we were thinking we can try it in rabbit to increase.
Efficiency of the transgenesis.
So what are the elements of the Sleeping Beauty system?
First of all you need.
You need your.
Your gene of interest.
It was a venous protein.
In our case with the.
CAG promoter Cake Promoter Works in all cell types and these are these.
Left and right recognition sites for the transpose is and the second component is the transpose itself.
You can use it as a as a plasmid, or you can make an in vitro transcription, and you can inject it together with your construct as an RNA.
We prefer to do this one so we just mix the two components and you can micro inject it into.
The primal closes, so the metal is very, very similar to the normal microinjection.
You just have to micro inject your.
Your zygotes, that's microinjection in rabbit, and you can inject into the panel close, or it's possible to micro inject into the cytoplasm of the cells after the microinjection.
Most of the stars survive, and then you have to transfer them to observe the pregnant female.
We made some refinement.
We don't make surgical methods.
We're using a special methods.
It's an endoscopic methods using the endoscope.
We just try to find the the ovary.
That's the ovary.
And then we try to find the beginning of the oviduct.
And when you found it then.
A little bit later on, when everything seems fine, then you just inject your MRI was into the episode of pregnant female and wait for the results.
What were the result?

These are the results, so we injected about five hundreds zygotes and transferred back to serve the pregnant females, and altogether we got 46 newborn and seven was transgenic, which is 15% efficiency.
This efficiency is much, much higher than the normal.
Transgenesis and we could establish four transgenic lines from this.
Found their animals.
These are the founder animals and if you look at them you can recognize that not all of the cells are positive in this.
Animals here and here and here you can find some cells which which are not green.
It means that these are almost six, which means that all of the folders were mosaic, but in the next generation.
You cannot see this more like effect, which is normal.
So the next step was to determine the integration sites and copy number of the integration.
This system always integrating into one copy.
But it is possible to integrate to different genomic sites.
We tested four different animals and in two cases there was just one integration sites.
There were two integration sites for one case and there were three integration size for the survey.
The transgenic line we determined the integration site in the single copy into grants, and it was in one case to the chromosome 19 and to chromosome eight in the.
In the other case.
In both cases there were no jeans around integration site, which is good.
So what was the expression?
The expression was very, very strong.
All this as expressed the transgene.
It's a liver section, and that's a test.
This section.
We couldn't find any silencing of the transgene.
Sometimes you can find silencing event in transposon mediated transgenesis.
Especially, it was shown in transgenic mice, but in our transgenic rabbits we couldn't find any silencing event.
So there's a summary, so the transposon mediated Transgenesis was much, much better than the normal microinjection.
The integration was random, it was single copy or low copy integration.
The expression was strong, and the transgene transmission was was fine.
The only problem with this method is that one that the cargo capacity is around 10 key B.
If you have a construct larger than.
Thank YB then the efficiency is going down and done, but now they are working on a new system where transposon mediated transgenesis can be done even in back bacterial artificial chromosomes.
So hopefully soon we have a new version of of the Sleeping Beauty.
So how we use this transgenic rabbits?

It was done not just for fun, to have a nice green rabbit, but we would like to establish some ESL line and using this GFP or this Venus protein, it's much easy to follow the cells and now we have some some collaboration with experimental surgery methods, especially in the corner.
Because then you can.
You can again follow what happens with the transferred tissue.
So that was the additive transgenesis.
And now let's see how you can do knockout or a targeted transgenesis in rabbits.
I don't want to talk too much about the the thing finger nucleus technology, the talent technology and crisp our system because Oscar told us everything about that.
I just want to show it in rabbits.
There was two papers where transgenic rabbits were done by the thing finger method.
The first one was an IG M knockout in the immuno globin locus was mutated and it was working very nicely.
That these are the founders so they have different folders for the first exam.
Then for the second Exxon and the result was that there was no IG M so they got.
The final type.
This is the first step for for a humanizing antibody production rabbit, which was done in Germany.
We have some experiences with Sing Finger nucleuses in rabbits.
It was very, very effective.
We use two different knockout in sing finger.
Unfortunately I cannot tell the names of the genes.
In one case I don't even know what was that because it was just down for a special company.
But I know that the efficiency was between 20 and 25 in both cases.

The founders were usually mosaic as it's the same effect which we could see in the in the case of the transposon mediated transgenesis, but all founders transmitted the transition to the next generation, which was very, very good.
There was 1 interesting thing that in one case the F1 generation was carrying a different mutation than you could see in the Founders error.
It means that there was a special.
Moses there was a two base pair deletion in the in the air and there was a four baseboard relation plus one in the F1 generation.
It is the same effect again.
The integration was after the first cleavage and that that's why it was possible that the Founders mutation was not exactly the same as in the in the F1 generation.
That's why we always suggest to test the F1 generation.
Very precisely not to not to believe, just that founder.
But why we have so many mosaic animals in in rabbits?
In the nucleus technology and in the in the normal microinjection, and in the transposon mediated transgenesis?
That's why because the the the mouse there is almost one day to have from a single cell stage to the two cell stage.
But in the rabbit it's much much faster when we watch the embryos in the morning, it's about 9:00 o'clock.
And by 1:00 PM so within 4 hours we have the two cell stage and that's why this time window is much much less and that's why we have more transgenic more Mosaic founders than in the mice and rats.
There are some talent experiments in in rabbits.
There is one published paper with two different knockouts.
It was it was working very nicely and we have started talent experiments in rabbits.
In our lab we have transferred almost 200 zygotes, and we.
Transferred two temp so the pregnant females 5 became pregnant and we got 15 newborns and these are very very newborns so they they are not.
Not a very cold so we have no results.
How many of them carrying the mutation?
Hope we hope that at least one will carry.
We tested in.
In the blast of this stage and we found that this time was working in rabbits, so hopefully we will get the results of this one.
And the last but not least, decrease power system.
The decrease part was extremely efficient in rabbits.
There was one paper publishing 10 different knockouts in just one paper, just to show how robust is in rabbits.
Usually they found.
Homozygous rabbits also so they they could find biallelic mutations, so it seems that for the rabbits decreased power system should be the best or the most efficient one.
So, as Oscar mentioned, not just knockout, but knocking is possible.
There is no published paper yet in rabbit with with no key nor Alex change, but I'm sure that soon there should be some Alex change experimenting in rabbit.
So just a summary.
These methods are relatively cheap, very, very specific, efficient in rabbits.
Any targeting even can be produced now in rabbit, which was impossible few years before, even a single base pair exchange can be tested in rabbits, and that's very, very important.
This technology is a traceless technology, which means that there is nothing in the.
Mutation which which you can which you can follow that it was really coming from a human.
It looks like deletions so big question is the regulation high?
You can regulate this type of transgenesis.
Of course, everybody want to recreate it, but I'm sure that it's almost impossible and these technologies open a new era for large animal models, not just for the rabbit.
I told you that the rabbit is a very very good model, but also for the peak.
You can do everything in the pig now using the same technology and sometimes the pig is even more better model than the rabbit models, so I'm sure that the new era is.
Coming and there should be some nice rabbit models and then the pig models for human diseases.
Thank you very much for your attention.
